newsitem.title: HUNGARY: HUNGARY BCE EASING MILLING WHEAT FUTURES DOMINATE.
newsitem.headline: HUNGARY BCE EASING MILLING WHEAT FUTURES DOMINATE.

text.p: Milling wheat futures finished lower on the Budapest Commodity Exchange (BCE) on Tuesday in meagre turnover and dealers said this could be the start of a downward trend.
"(Brokerage) Order was the only buyer before, but now it also began to sell," said Robert Monostori of Agrimpex.
Milling wheat prices for January 1997 closed at 28,220 forints, down 490. March 1997 finished at 29,000 forints, down 250, and lowered by 280 forints for May to end at 29,420 forints.
"It looks like even the mills have an oversupply and they might appear on the selling side as well," Monostori said.
September 1997 milling wheat contracts rose slightly by 100 forints to end at 22,300 while the other maturities reamined unchanged.
Maize futures rose slightly for May and July 1997, ending at 20,850 forints, up 80 and 21,600 forints, up 100.
"Traders have started to close positions, that's why prices are rising," Monostori said, adding that little else but wheat and maize was traded on Tuesday.
Total turnover for the grain section was 392.5 million forints or 795 lots, of which 588 were milling wheat, 182 maize and 25 blackseed contracts.
Lot size is 20,000 kgs for all contracts.
